sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Anton Tyschenko)
articles.description: Every once in a while, we publish [freebies](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/category/freebies) related to different occasions and themes. We hope that with this icon set, everyone will be able to find their own use case for these icons in particular. Today, we present to you three icon sets designed by the creative folks at GraphicSurf — all free for personal and commercial use.
articles.title: Freebie: Wayfinding Icon Sets (164 Icons, PNG, SVG, AI, EPS)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: We’ll explore fluid typography principles, use-cases, implementation with CSS clamp() and an interactive fluid typography calculator.
articles.title: Modern Fluid Typography Using CSS Clamp

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: In [Part 1](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/01/ten-tips-aspiring-designer-beginners-part1/), Luis Ouriach shared advice he wished he had when starting out in his career. In this second and last part of this series, Luis continues sharing tips that helped him grow and become a better designer throughout the years.
articles.title: Ten Tips For Aspiring Designer Beginners (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Don)
articles.description: If you’re a developer who’s thinking about building a platform that requires a code editor in one form or another, then this article is for you. This article explains how to create a web code editor that displays the result in real time with the help of some HTML, CSS and JavaScript.
articles.title: Building A Web Code Editor

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kate Kalcevich)
articles.description: Accessibility must be a permanent program within organizations, much like security. In this article, Kate Kalcevich shares tips on which skills and questions to keep in mind when hiring for digital accessibility roles.
articles.title: How To Hire For Digital Accessibility Roles

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ahmad Shadeed)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll be taking a closer look at two gradients: `conic-gradient` and `radial-gradient`. You’ll see how each one of them works in detail, what the differences and similarities are between them, how and where to use them, and some use cases for each.
articles.title: A Deep CSS Dive Into Radial And Conic Gradients

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Scott Himmer)
articles.description: Product roadmaps are often treated as a series of checkboxes. But they are more than that. In this article, Scott Himmer explains how internal partnerships, research, design systems, and regular touch bases can help make sure that your product roadmap is a successful one.
articles.title: Changing A Tire On A Moving Car (Or How To Improve Product Roadmaps)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: In this article (the first part in a series of two), Luis Ouriach shares advice that he wishes he has when starting out in his career. These tips come from his experience as a user interface and product designer for close to ten years, and if you’re starting just now, then read on!
articles.title: Ten Tips For Aspiring Designer Beginners (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Aleksandra Nagornaia)
articles.description: Figma has advanced enough where it now supports some powerful concepts that can help with the flexibility and maintainability of a design system. In this article, Sasha explains why she finds the Systems Designer position so rewarding — and it’s not only because of how fast certain tools have developed to help her master challenges she faces in her work projects.
articles.title: Composition-Based Design System In Figma

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: What better way could there be to start the new year than with some fresh inspiration? Our collection of wallpapers for January 2022 is bound to put a smile on your face — and maybe spark new ideas, too.
articles.title: New Year, Fresh Desktop (January 2022 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Scoping, estimating, and running digital projects can often feel like an exercise in futility. In this article, Paul Boag explains why you need to start breaking your projects down into manageable phases and why that’s the best way to achieve significant benefits.
articles.title: How To Price Projects And Manage Scope Creep

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paulina Hetman)
articles.description: Have you already built and published a Gatsby theme? In this article, Paulina Hetman explains how Gatsby themes work and what problems they can solve by comparing Gatsby themes with their WordPress counterparts.
articles.title: Building Gatsby Themes For WordPress-Powered Websites

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alyssa Holland)
articles.description: Range inputs have notoriously been a pain to style. Each browser renders the input differently requiring you to use vendor prefixes in order to create a cohesive look and feel. In this article, we’ll take a look at the quirkiness of the HTML range input and demonstrate how to style the input to look consistent across all major browsers.
articles.title: Creating A Custom Range Input That Looks Consistent Across All Browsers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: A meaningful user experience is what can set your site apart from others. But what makes an experience truly meaningful? And how to achieve that? The tools, tips, and resources in this post not only help you to come up with a UX strategy that works for you and your team but also to circumvent potential UX pitfalls.
articles.title: Useful UX Guidelines, Tools And Resources

articles.description: HTML Tables are simple to use for rendering small amounts of data. But they can be hard for users to work with when they display a lot of data.  Features like sorting, filtering, and pagination make it easier to work with many rows of data. We can easily implement those
articles.title: How to Convert a Static HTML Table to a Dynamic JavaScript Data Grid

articles.description: The Result-Error Pattern helps you hide try-catch blocks, simplify error handling, and encapsulate cleanup operations.
articles.title: How to Simplify Asynchronous JavaScript using the Result-Error Pattern

articles.description: In this article, we'll learn how to set up a CI/CD pipeline with GitHub Actions and AWS. I've divided the guide into three parts to help you work through it: First, we'll cover some important terminology so you're not lost in a bunch of big buzzwords. Second, we'll set
articles.title: How to Setup a CI/CD Pipeline with GitHub Actions and AWS

articles.description: Adjusting, visualizing, and sharing machine learning models can be much easier with a sleek user interface. We just published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you how to use Gradio to create intuitive user interfaces for machine learning models. Abdul from 1littlecoder developed this course.
articles.title: Create User Interfaces for Machine Learning Models Using Gradio

articles.description: As a developer, how often have you seen a repository with packages that are out of date? New package updates generally include new features, performance improvements, and security fixes. But keeping track of all outdated dependencies in your project can be really boring and a time consuming task, especially if
articles.title: How to Keep Your Package Dependencies Up to Date on Azure DevOps

articles.description: Network applications are computer applications that participate in a computer network. These applications talk to each other by plugging into the network.  For example, when you visit google.com, your browser acts as a network application that leverages the Internet to talk to the network application running on Google's computer.
articles.title: Computer Networking Tutorial – How Network Applications Talk Over the Internet

articles.description: Data types can be a bit of a mind boggling concept. But as programmers, we use data types everyday – so they're something we should understand.  Question is, how does the computer store these data types? It can't possibly treat every data type the same. In JavaScript, data types are split
articles.title: Primitive vs Reference Data Types in JavaScript

articles.description: This article is about how working as an independent contractor for a web design agency helped me to start my own freelance business.
articles.title: How Working as an Independent Contractor Can Help You Start Your Own Freelance Dev Business

articles.description: Patreon is a subscription management system for creators. Although it offers a default button snippet, you can add a custom button that includes your preferred design and call to action to increase your click through rate. In this article you will learn how to create a simple custom Patreon link
articles.title: How to Create a Custom Patreon Button

articles.description: If you ask a group of developers what Linux is, most of them will probably say it's an open-source operating system. Those with more technical knowledge will probably call it a kernel. For me, though, Linux is not just an operating system or a kernel. For me, it's freedom. The
articles.title: The Arch Linux Handbook
